Snickers at Eleanor's 'star-light' comment, showing a confident but somewhat dismissive attitude.
Borrows Alison's bag without permission and holds on desperately when asked to give it back; then tries to hide the dog's escape and pleads not to be reported.
Desperately holds onto Alison's bag and tries to hide the small animal inside, then panics and throws it out the window when caught.
Hangs his head, awaiting reproach after news of missing dog.
Nervously approaches Clayton Harding to ask for a favor (doing a story).
Congratulates Clayton on his award, attempts to make conversation despite awkwardness.
Hovering nervously and unsure what to say in a tense situation.
Thanks Clayton enthusiastically and embraces the role of 'Hit Man' with eagerness and good humor.
Insists politely to Sophie Maes' assistant that he is not a stalker and shows concern about Sophie being upset.
Resents being bribed to write flattering pieces but admits to choosing to gush sycophantically.
Smiles back at Alison, sharing a moment of mutual understanding.
Gives Alison advice about getting a boyfriend who shows up, then quickly leaves awkwardly.
Walks in confidently with an attractive blonde woman to surprise Lawrence Maddox with a stripper gift.
Asks sincerely why his story was rejected, shows vulnerability by staring at his feet.
Calls Vincent Lepak a 'talentless, pretentious little twat', expresses harsh criticism in strong language.
Engages in tense confrontation with Clayton Harding but maintains composure and uses humor to diffuse tension ('Looks like I was too late to save you after all')
Imagines coworkers applauding him, indicating a desire for acceptance and positive social connection
Admits to feeling hated and expresses appreciation that Alison talks to him despite being 'abusive'; shows embarrassment and vulnerability.
Offers Alison another drink to maintain friendly interaction.
Surreptitiously drops his credit card by Sophie's feet, suggesting possible intent to get her attention or interact covertly.
Feels troubled and physically pained when hearing Maddox praised and seeing him interact with Sophie.
Insists on reclaiming his business card and defends his use of 'Hon' as short for 'Honourable'
Tells Lawrence Maddox to 'shut up' in front of others, showing irritation
Engages in a quick, teasing nationalistic banter with Maddox and Sophie, causing Sophie to giggle but Maddox to dislike it
Attempts to correct the mistaken name on his business card politely and tries to reclaim it.
Engages in a verbal exchange with Lawrence Maddox, showing quick wit and confidence despite the teasing.
Walks off after a tense exchange instead of escalating the conflict further.
Claims a false title (implying 'Honourable') to impress someone, which might be seen as deceptive.
Greets Mrs Harding politely with a compliment about the party.
Muttering 'Choke. Choke.' to himself while watching Alison and Maddox, suggesting negativity or ill-will.
Rejects the suggestion of taking cocaine politely.
Attempts to warmly reconnect with Rachel Petkoff by greeting her enthusiastically.
Snorts dismissively at Rachel's compliment toward Lawrence, indicating sarcasm and dismissiveness.
Expresses disbelief and moral judgment about Maddox's affair, showing emotional reaction toward Alison's feelings.
Allows Alison to physically kick his injured leg without protest, showing tolerance and some playfulness.
Lies beside the pool nursing a hangover, appearing gloomy and withdrawn, showing emotional vulnerability.
Listens quietly and offers to get food for Sophie
Watches Sophie with concern but does not press when she avoids food to avoid photographers
Is speechless when Sophie talks about coke making her horny
Runs desperately to find the Wizard Dentist and brings help
Hurries past Alison but then stops and stares back at her, showing concern.
Tells Alison she can't drive drunk and she needs to sleep it off somewhere, showing care for her safety.
Holds Alison to stop her falling when she sways forward and looks uncertain about what to do, indicating compassion and concern.
Responds calmly and tries to keep Alison safe despite her hostility and insults.
Interrupts Alison when overwhelmed, telling her to be quiet and avoids engaging deeply with emotional issues.
Attempts to comfort Alison despite discomfort, showing some emotional awareness and empathy.
Carries an intoxicated Alison up the stairs to his apartment despite the inconvenience and disturbance to his neighbors.
Responds to Alison vomiting on his shorts with reluctant but tolerant acceptance.
Hisses at Alison to be quiet to avoid waking neighbor but stops when confronted by Mrs Kowalski, showing awareness and slight discomfort.
Shows a sickly smile and freezes when confronted by Mrs Kowalski, indicating awkwardness and possible insincerity.
Carries an intoxicated Alison upstairs carefully, attempts to keep the situation discreet by telling her to be quiet to avoid waking the neighbor.
Freezes awkwardly and manages a sickly smile when confronted by Mrs Kowalski, showing discomfort and inability to handle the situation confidently.
Attempts to get Alison's address and wake her up while driving but fails as she is unresponsive and snores loudly.
Attempts to explain the cocaine wrap is not for him, trying to deflect suspicion.
Closes his eyes and trails off when caught in an awkward situation.
Responds with 'I think you should lie down Alison' to her invasive or embarrassing comments.
Attempts to explain that the cocaine is not for him and tries to mitigate the awkward situation, though quickly realizes it is unhelpful and trails off.
Appears visibly uncomfortable and overwhelmed by the presence of his father and Alison's behavior, showing a lack of confidence.
Avoids Alison's eye when she realizes his identity and does not volunteer information about his background.
Smiles weakly after being indirectly mocked and criticized.
Sits alone awkwardly with Richard Young and tells him 'You should have said you were coming...'
Checks on Alison to ensure she is okay and quietly leaves to not disturb her.
Cooks and hums happily, showing domestic skill and a relaxed confidence.
Comforts Alison empathetically, encouraging her to stay.
Makes a humorous, confident remark about his father's past relationships, demonstrating social wit.
Answers Alison's questions about his mother with composed and honest responses.
Fiddles with his ring on his finger without thinking, revealing internal vulnerability or distraction.
Serves Alison an English fry-up as a hangover cure, showing attentiveness but Alison's adverse reaction undermines the skill.
Reads Alison's private notebook without permission but admits guilt.
Compliments Alison's writing and asks to read more.
Gives Alison a thoughtful present to cheer her up.
Invites Alison to listen to the record at his place after she reveals she lacks a turntable.
Invites Alison to listen to music and dances with her, leading to shared laughter and enjoyment.
Secretly watches Alison with a smitten, caring demeanor.
Listens sadly to women laughing inside, indicating sensitivity and possibly feeling excluded.
Reacts with wonder to Alison's compliment, shows hopefulness and kindness in interpreting her behavior.
Panics and hides when caught listening, showing insecurity and lack of assertiveness but not hostility.
Attempts nervously to ask Alison on a date, showing vulnerability and sincere interest.
Compliments Vincent's costume despite Vincent denying wearing one.
Muttered insults exchanged silently with Vincent (calls him 'wanker').
Attempts to approach Alison nervously and tries to talk to her.
Interrupts Alison and insists 'Me first' in conversation while mumbling through his fake teeth.
Responds to Alison's news about Maddox leaving his wife with feigned enthusiasm ('Well...that's...that's brilliant.') and an awkward silence follows.
Kneels down on the sidewalk begging, stares dumbly across the street as the limousine drives away.
Sits in front of Clayton Harding listening to updates on staff departures and new assignments without apparent input or questions.
Is assigned to hold the fort temporarily at I Spy magazine and to write a profile on Vincent Lepak, apparently having advanced to the 'next room' unexpectedly.
Receives expensive gifts (Rolex watch) and enjoys socializing at a movie premiere, laughing with a producer and high-fiving a celebrity.
Appears self-absorbed and focused on status symbols (Rolex watch, expensive suit, mingling with glitterati) without evidence of sincere connection or kindness.
Questions Eleanor about the Golden Globe nomination despite being told it hasn't been announced yet, showing awareness and caution.
Stares stunned when offered the cover story assignment, indicating surprise but potentially processing the opportunity.
Hesitates before entering the club, showing possible insecurity or awe rather than confident action.
Thanks Alison politely and inquires about her novel, encouraging her to keep at it and expressing belief in her.
Hands Alison detailed notes on her novel, demonstrating thoughtfulness and support.
Laughs and makes a half-joking, half-meaning-it comment about things going wrong, showing a degree of self-awareness and vulnerability.
Does not invite Alison inside and only briefly engages with her despite her awkward attempts, suggesting emotional distance.
Refuses to give Sophie the ring despite pressure, showing restraint.
Is isolated and struggles with substance abuse and emotional pain alone in his hotel room.
Claps along with others at the Golden Globes, joins in applause
Grabs Sophie's arm and tries to forcibly retrieve his ring, despite her clear resistance and attempts to disengage
Insists Sophie is not 'the One' and behaves aggressively, causing a public scene and distress
Ignores social cues and intervenes physically, drawing attention negatively and disrupting others
Slaps the back of Vincent Lepak's head, knocking his sunglasses off and then stamps on them while fleeing security.
Plunges forward to join his own kind among the paparazzi despite bruises and ripped collar, showing determination to be with his group.
Stares out the cab window and insists to stop the car at the park showcasing a personal, possibly sentimental impulse.
Smiles upon seeing Alison at the outdoor screening, indicating a friendly or affectionate feeling.
Stops walking towards Alison and turns away after seeing her resting her head on another man's shoulder, showing restraint and respect for her situation.
